answers.answer: Hello,Lantus is a long acting insulin. You may also need to be taking a fast acting insulin (Humalog, novalog etc). with your meals.You can look up basal-bolus insulin to see more about this.How much carbs do you eat with each meal?  If you follow the typical recommendations, they may have you eating large amounts of carbs (ie. 50 - 100 g) every time you eat.  If you reduce how much carbs you eat at each meal, you may be able to reduce your insulin dose / may avoid spikes.They can test for type of diabetes even on insulin.  Antibody tests are usually done for type 1.  Also c-peptide tests to see how much insulin you are making.You can google low carb diets and diabetes.  There is  plenty of information.

question: I was diagnosed with diabetes about a month ago, but they never tested me for type 1 or 2. I finally have my fasting glucose down to 81 with help from Janumet and Lantus. My problem is my blood sugar still spikes to the 270+ range 2 hours after eating. I am following the diet they gave me religiously and watch my carb and sugar intake faithfully. My question is, is this typical of type 1 or 2, and can they still test me even though I'm on insulin?
title: Diabetes Testing?
